description.narrative: GoT's Justice System better protects the rights of women and children in contact/conflict with the law and is better able to respond to their needs

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: GoT's Justice System better protects the rights of women and children in contact/conflict with the law and is better able to respond to their needs

description.narrative: Government of Tanzania's Justice System better protects the rights of women and children in contact/conflict with the law and is better able to respond to their needs | Status:On-track | As-of Date:29/07/2016

title.narrative: % of detained children in approved schools with reintegration plans

baseline.value: 0 detained children in approved schools have reintegration plans

actual.value: 2016:All 25 children at the Approved School have reintegration plans. Four children will complete primary level education on 9th September 2016, and arrangements are being made with the Social Welfare Officers in the areas where children came from, to properly integrate them in their communities. Trainin

title.narrative: % increase in child abuse cases reported to GCD (reference period 12 months)

baseline.value: 1912 cases of GBV and child abuse were reported to all the Gender and Children's Desks in Iringa and Mbeya in 2012 = 15% of cases reported in the two regions.

target.value: 2016:Iringa: 30%, Mufindi: 30%, Njombe: 30%, Makete: 30%, Mbeya: 30%, Mbarali: 30%, Shinyanga: 30% Kisarawe:30% Kibaha: 30% West district: 30%

actual.value: 2016:At the time of submission, the Tanzanian Police Force had not consolidated or made available VAC and GBV information. During the reporting period training for the police was held on the use of newly introduced registers to capture and analyze VAC and GBV cases. It is anticipated that the registers

title.narrative: Incorporation of international standards for child and juvenile justice in the justice system

baseline.value: Inadequate reflection of international standards in child and juvenile justice

target.value: 2016:Key international child justice standards and norms are incorporated in Tanzania's legal and policy framework

actual.value: 2016:Substantial progress has been made vis-a-vis integrating international standards for children into police guidelines and procedures, as well as in relation to developing guidelines and regulations for child friendly courts and juvenile courts. During this reporting period, Tanzania Prisons Services

title.narrative: # of children in conflict with the law receiving legal support

baseline.value: No formal system of legal assistance for children in conflict with the law

target.value: 2016:>1500 children in conflict with the law receive legal support in DSM and Mbeya region, replication of the programme in Zanzibar

actual.value: 2016:A cumulative 1,522 children in conflict with the law on both the mainland and Zanzibar have received a combination of child supporter assistance in police stations, legal aid, and/or community rehabilitation.

title.narrative: # of regions with child friendly courts

actual.value:
2016:A Juvenile Court has been established in Kisarawe district, while the Mbeya Juvenile Court is still under construction.
In Zanzibar, 1 Region (Urban West) has an operational Children's Court. Construction is underway on a new Children's Court in North Region which will be completed in the second
